Topic: African American Theater


This course is a survey of African American theatre and performance from the early 20th century to the present. Plays will be read in the context of African American history and Black political thought. We will investigate larger social, political, philosophical, religious, and artistic movements and their impact on African American theatre.  Major issues including double consciousness, color politics, cultural nationalism, racial stereotypes, civil rights, and social protest will be explored. Students will be exposed to the fundamentals of Black Feminist/Womanist thought; and locate the Black female dramatists, voice in within Black theatre theory. Additionally, students work with archival materials from the Stuart A. Rose Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library to not only enhance their learning but will also develop skills and confidence in archival research. By examining drama from Black playwrights, this course aims to expand the students, understanding of the complexity of the systems of disadvantage affecting African Americans in the United States.
course_description: A systematic reading of plays through dramatic structure as genre, exploring such major forms as tragedy or comedy.
